'''''Stropharia ambigua''''', sometimes known as the '''questionable Stropharia''', is a [[saprotrophic nutrition|saprotrophic]] [[agaric]] mushroom, commonly fruiting in [[leaf litter]] and [[wood chips]] in the western United States and Canada.

==Description==
The [[cap (mycology)|cap]] is {{convert|3|to|15|cm|in|abbr=on}} broad, obtuse to convex, becomes plain or uplifted in age, has a smooth surface, is slimy when moist, and yellowish. The [[flesh (mycology)|flesh]] is white, thick, and soft. The [[gill (mycology)|gills]] are pale gray and gradually darkens to purplish-gray or purplish-black.<ref name="hunter"/> The gills occasionally pull away from the stipe with age.<ref name="hip"/> The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is {{convert|6|to|18|cm|in|abbr=on}} long and is stuffed or hollow. The [[partial veil|veil]] is soft and white. The [[spore print]] is dark purplish to nearly black. The species fruits in the spring and fall.<ref name="hunter"/> It does not have a [[volva (mycology)|volva]].<ref name="hip"/>

===Edibility===
The species has been said to taste like old leaves.<ref name="Demystified"/> Because of conflicting reports that they received on the edibility of this species, the authors [[Orson K. Miller, Jr.]] and Hope Miller do not recommend eating it.<ref name=Miller2006>{{cite book | last = K. Miller | first = Orson | authorlink = |author2=Miller, Hope  | title = North American Mushrooms: A Field Guide to Edible and Inedible Fungi | publisher = Globe Pequot | date = 2006 | location = | page = 256 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=zjvXkLpqsEgC&pg=PA256 | isbn = 978-0-7627-3109-1 }}</ref> [[Alexander Hanchett Smith]] and Nancy S. Weber said that the species is not poisonous.<ref name="hunter"/> [[David Arora]] does not recommend eating this species.<ref name="hip"/> The authors of ''Poisonous plants of California'' said that the species is suspected of being poisonous.<ref name=Fuller1986>{{cite book | last = Multiple authors | first = Fuller Thomas C.; McClintock, Elizabeth May | title = Poisonous Plants of California | publisher = University of California Press | date = 1986 | location = | page = 53 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=GDpCNKm7xTQC&pg=PA53 | isbn = 978-0-520-05569-8 }}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Stropharia ambigua'' appears in late fall as a solitary to scattered mushroom or in groups on rich [[humus]], usually under [[conifers]]. It can also be found with [[alder]] and other [[hardwoods]] in the [[Pacific Coast]].<ref name="Demystified">{{cite book | last = Arora | first = David | authorlink = | title = Mushrooms Demystified: A Comprehensive Guide to the Fleshy Fungi | publisher = Ten Speed Press | date = 1986 | location = | page = 378 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=L-4ajFDPlxgC&pg=PA378 | isbn = 978-0-89815-169-5 }}</ref> It has frequently been found in disturbed areas, such as where wood was handled.<ref name="hunter">{{cite book | last = Smith | first = Alexander Hanchett | authorlink = | last2= Weber |first2=Nancy S. | title = The Mushroom Hunter's Field Guide | publisher = University of Michigan Press | date = 1980 | location = | page = 226 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=TYI4f6fqrfkC&pg=RA5-PA226 | isbn = 978-0-472-85610-7}}</ref> The species invade outdoor mushroom beds after wood chips have decomposed by a primary [[saprotrophic nutrition|saprotroph]].<ref name=Stamets2000>{{cite book | last = Stamets | first = Paul | authorlink = | title = Growing gourmet and medicinal mushrooms | publisher = Ten Speed Press | date = 2000 | location = | page = 12 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=y1fnacRg1AYC&pg=PA12 | isbn = 978-1-58008-175-7}}</ref> It favors a cold and damp environment.<ref name="hip">{{cite book | last = Arora | first = David | authorlink = | title = All That the Rain Promises and More: A Hip Pocket Guide to Western Mushrooms | publisher = Ten Speed Press | date = 1991 | location = | pages = 126 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=87ct90d4B9gC&pg=PA126 | isbn = 978-0-89815-388-0 }}</ref>
